questions.prompt: The line integral ∫_C f(x,y) ds represents what?
options: Area of fence above curve C
questions.correctAnswer: Area of fence above curve C
questions.explanation: ∫_C f ds gives the area of the "fence" with height f(x,y) above the curve C

questions.prompt: For a curve r(t) = <x(t), y(t)> from t = a to t = b, what is ds?
questions.explanation: The differential arc length is ds = |r'(t)| dt = √((dx/dt)² + (dy/dt)²) dt

questions.prompt: The line integral ∫_C f ds depends on the orientation of curve C.
questions.explanation: ∫_C f ds is independent of orientation (reversing direction doesn't change the value)

questions.prompt: The work done by force field F along curve C is given by which line integral?
questions.explanation: Work = ∫_C F · dr = ∫_C F · T ds, where T is the unit tangent vector

questions.prompt: For F = <P, Q> and C parameterized by r(t), what is ∫_C F · dr equal to?
questions.explanation: F · dr = <P,Q> · <dx/dt, dy/dt> dt = (P dx/dt + Q dy/dt) dt

questions.prompt: A vector field F is conservative if there exists a potential function f such that F = ∇f.
questions.explanation: F is conservative ⟺ F = ∇f for some scalar function f (the potential function)

questions.prompt: For a conservative field F = ∇f, what is ∫_C F · dr from point A to point B?
questions.explanation: The Fundamental Theorem for Line Integrals: ∫_C ∇f · dr = f(B) - f(A)

questions.prompt: If F is conservative, then ∫_C F · dr = 0 for any closed curve C.
questions.explanation: For conservative fields, line integrals over closed curves are zero (path independence)

questions.prompt: For F = <P, Q> in 2D, F is conservative if which condition holds?
questions.explanation: In a simply connected region, F = <P,Q> is conservative ⟺ ∂P/∂y = ∂Q/∂x (curl = 0)

questions.prompt: What is the flux of vector field F across curve C?
questions.explanation: Flux = ∫_C F · n ds, where n is the unit normal vector to the curve

questions.prompt: For a surface S parameterized by r(u,v), what is the surface area element dS?
questions.explanation: The surface area element is dS = |r_u × r_v| du dv, using the cross product magnitude

questions.prompt: The surface integral ∫∫_S f(x,y,z) dS can be used to find the surface area when f = 1.
questions.explanation: When f = 1, ∫∫_S 1 dS equals the surface area of S

questions.prompt: The flux of F through surface S is given by which integral?
questions.explanation: Flux = ∫∫_S F · n dS = ∫∫_S F · dS, where n is the unit normal vector

questions.prompt: For a surface given by z = g(x,y), what is the upward normal vector?
questions.explanation: For F(x,y,z) = z - g(x,y) = 0, ∇F = <-g_x, -g_y, 1> points upward (positive z-component)

questions.prompt: An oriented surface has a continuously varying what?
questions.explanation: An oriented surface has a continuously varying unit normal vector field
